facts.text: This is a petition under article 32 of the Constitution filed in Original Jurisdiction as Petition No. 55 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 55 of 1954. Under article 32 of the Constitution for the enforcement of fundamental rights. C. Chatterjee,  J. B. Dadachanji and Rajinder Narain, with him  for the petitioners. V. Tambe and I. N. Shroff for the respondent. 1954. April 5.

facts.text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by JAGANNADHADAS J.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. April 5. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by JAGANNADHADAS J.-This is a petition under article 32 of the Constitution and is presented to this Court under the following circumstances.

facts.text: Petitioner No. 1 was an Agricultural Demonstrator of the Government of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: Petitioner No. I before us was an Agricultural Demonstrator of the Government of Madras and was employed as an Assistant Marketing Officer in Central Provinces and Berar for the purchase and movement of blackgram and other grains on behalf of the Madras Government.

facts.text: Petitioner No. 1 was employed as an Assistant Marketing Officer in Central Provinces and Berar for the purchase and movement of blackgram and other grains on behalf of the Madras Government.

anchor.surface_text: Petitioner No. I before us was an Agricultural Demonstrator of the Government of Madras and was employed as an Assistant Marketing Officer in Central Provinces and Berar for the purchase and movement of blackgram and other grains on behalf of the Madras Government.

facts.text: Petitioner No. 1, the second petitioner and 44 others are under prosecution before Shri K. E. Pandey, a Special Magistrate of Nagpur, Madhya Pradesh, in Case No. I of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: He, as well as the second petitioner and 44 others, are under prosecution before Shri K. E. Pandey, a Special Magistrate of Nagpur, Madhya Pradesh, in Case No. I of 1949 pending before him on charges of cheating, attempt to commit cheating, criminal breach of trust and criminal conspiracy,

facts.text: The prosecution is on charges of cheating, attempt to commit cheating, criminal breach of trust and criminal conspiracy, i.e., offences under section 420 read with section 120-B or 109 of the Indian Penal Code, section 409 and section 409 read with section 120-B of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: He, as well as the second petitioner and 44 others, are under prosecution before Shri K. E. Pandey, a Special Magistrate of Nagpur, Madhya Pradesh, in Case No. I of 1949 pending before him on charges of cheating, attempt to commit cheating, criminal breach of trust and criminal conspiracy, i.e., for offences punishable under section 420 read with section 120-B or 109 of the Indian Penal Code, section 409 and section 409 read with section 120-B of the Indian Penal Code

facts.text: By reason of the acts committed by the accused, the Government of Madras had to incur an expenditure of Rs. 3,57,147-10-0 in excess of the amount due.

anchor.surface_text: and the allegation is that by reason of the acts committed by the accused, the Government of Madras had to incur an expenditure of Rs. 3,57,147-10-0 in excess of the amount due.

facts.text: Shri K. E. Pandey, the Special Magistrate, was appointed by the Madhya Pradesh Government under section 14 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Magistrate before whom the case is number pending was appointed by the Madhya Pradesh Government under section 14 of the Criminal Procedure Code, and as the first petitioner was a servant of the Government of Madras, the prosecution against him has been initiated by sanction given by the Government of Madras under section 197 1  of the Criminal Procedure Code.

facts.text: The first petitioner was a servant of the Government of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Magistrate before whom the case is number pending was appointed by the Madhya Pradesh Government under section 14 of the Criminal Procedure Code, and as the first petitioner was a servant of the Government of Madras, the prosecution against him has been initiated by sanction given by the Government of Madras under section 197 1  of the Criminal Procedure Code.

facts.text: Prosecution against the first petitioner was initiated by sanction given by the Government of Madras under section 197(1) of the Criminal Procedure Code.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Magistrate before whom the case is number pending was appointed by the Madhya Pradesh Government under section 14 of the Criminal Procedure Code, and as the first petitioner was a servant of the Government of Madras, the prosecution against him has been initiated by sanction given by the Government of Madras under section 197 1  of the Criminal Procedure Code.

facts.text: The present petition is for quashing the proceedings on the ground of their invalidity.

anchor.surface_text: The validity of the prosecution is challenged on various grounds, and the present petition is for quashing the proceedings on the ground of their invalidity.

facts.text: The trial has not yet commenced.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the second ground which is put forward on the authority of the Privy Council case of Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King 2 , it is admitted that the trial has number yet companymenced.

facts.text: Questions raised were previously dealt with before the High Court by applications under article 226 and decided against the petitioners. No appeals were taken to this Court against those orders.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, all the points raised on behalf of the petitioners fail, and this petition must be dismissed. It is desirable to observe that the questions above dealt with appear to have been raised before the High Court at previous stages by means of applications under article 226 and decided against. No appeals to this Court have been taken against the orders therein.

facts.text: Shri K. L. Pandey was first appointed as a Special Magistrate for the trial of the case.

Pandey who was first appointed as a Special Magistrate for the trial of the case, and to whose file on such appointment this case was transferred,

facts.text: Shri K. L. Pandey was later appointed as acting Sessions Judge for some time and ceased to have this case before him.

anchor.surface_text: In addition to the above three points, learned counsel for the petitioners has also raised a further point that in the present case Shri K. L. Pandey who was first appointed as a Special Magistrate for the trial of the case, and to whose file on such appointment this case was transferred, was later on appointed as acting Sessions Judge for some time and ceased to have this case before him.

facts.text: Shri K. L. Pandey reverted back from his position as acting Sessions Judge to his original post.

facts.text: The petition is dismissed.

issues.text: Whether Section 14 of the Criminal Procedure Code, in so far as it authorises the Provincial Government to confer upon any person all or any of the powers conferred or conferrable by or under the Code on a Magistrate of the first, second or third class in respect of particular cases and thereby to constitute a Special Magistrate for the trial of an individual case, violates the guarantee under article 14 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: 1 Section 14 of the Criminal Procedure Code, in so far as it authorises the Provincial Government to confer upon any person all or any of the powers conferred or conferrable by or under the Code on a Magistrate of the first, second or third class in respect of particular cases and thereby to constitute a Special Magistrate for the trial of an individual case, violates the guarantee under article 14 of the Constitution

issues.text: Whether the sanction given under section 197(1) of the Criminal Procedure Code for the prosecution as against the first petitioner is invalid, inasmuch as the order of the Madras Government granting the sanction does not disclose that all the facts constituting the offences to be charged were placed before the sanctioning authority nor does the sanction state the time or place of the occurrence or the transactions involved in it, or the persons with whom the offences were committed?

anchor.surface_text: The sanction given under section 197 1 of the Criminal Procedure Code for the prosecution as against the first petitioner is invalid, inasmuch as the order of the Madras Government granting the sanction does number disclose that all the facts constituting the offences to be charged were placed before the sanctioning authority number does the sanction state the time or place of the occurrence or the transactions involved in it, or the persons with whom the offences were companymitted. This contention is raised relying on the Privy Council case in Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King 1

issues.text: Even if the sanction under section 197(1) of the Criminal Procedure Code is valid, whether it is for the very Government which accords the sanction to specify also the Court before which the trial is to be held under section 197(2) and in the absence of any such specification by the said Government, the power under section 14 of the Criminal Procedure Code of appointing a Special Magistrate for the trial of the case cannot be exercised by the Madhya Pradesh Government?

anchor.surface_text: Even if the sanction under section 197 1 of the Criminal Procedure Code is valid, it is for the very Government which accords the sanction to specify also the Court before A.I.R. 1948 P.C. 82. which the trial is to be held under section 197 2 and in the absence -of any such specification by the said Government, the power under section 14 of the Criminal Procedure Code of appointing a Special Magistrate for the trial of the case cannot be exercised by the Madhya Pradesh Government.

issues.text: Whether, in the present case, Shri K. E. Pandey who was first appointed as a Special Magistrate for the trial of the case, and to whose file on such appointment this case was transferred, was later on appointed as acting Sessions Judge for some time and ceased to have this case before him, and reverted back, without a fresh notification appointing him as Special Magistrate and transferring the case to him as such, he can be said to be seized of this case as Special Magistrate?

anchor.surface_text: It is the third point that has been somewhat seriously pressed before us. The companytention of learned companynsel for the petitioners is based on sub-section  2  of section 197 of the Criminal Procedure Code... The argument is that it is for the very Government which sanctioned the prosecution under section 197 1  to specify the Court before which the trial is to be held and numberother,

arguments.court_reasoning: No policy of protection in s197(2); permissive; non-exercise no implication; s197(2) on court, s14 on person

arguments.claim: Powers under s197(2) and s14 are compatible; s197(2) concerns specifying the court, s14 concerns the person functioning as magistrate

anchor.surface_text: This entire argument, however, is based on a misconception of the respective scopes of the powers under, section 197 2  and section 14. The one relates to the Court and the other to the Person. Under sub-section  2  of section 197, the sanctioning Government may specify a. Court for the trial of the case but is number bound to do so.

arguments.claim: s197(2) not inspired by protection policy like s197(1); for convenience, complexity etc.

anchor.surface_text: This argument is farfetched. In the first instance, there is numberreason to think that section 197 2  is inspired by any policy of protection of the companycerned public servant, as section 197 1  is. There can be numberquestion of protection involved by an accused being tried by one Court rather than by another at the choice of the Government.

holdings.text: A law vesting discretion in an authority under such circumstances cannot be said to be discriminatory as such, and is therefore not hit by article 14 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 197(2) concerns specifying the Court (permissive), Section 14 concerns appointing the person/magistrate; distinct powers, no exclusion or implication from non-exercise; no protection policy in 197(2).

holdings.text: Under sub-section (2) of section 197, the sanctioning Government may specify a Court for the trial of the case but is not bound to do so.

anchor.surface_text: Under sub-section (2) of section 197, the sanctioning Government may specify a. Court for the trial of the case but is not bound to do so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power under s197(2) is permissive, not mandatory; non-specification does not preclude s14.
